Degenerative joint disease , bilateral knees . PRESENT ILLNESS : The patient is a 67 year old white male with progressive debilitating bilateral knee pain times two years . The patient states that he can no longer walk as much as an eighth of a mile . He needs assistance to get in and out of a chair , has difficulty with stairs . He takes Naprosyn 500 mg p.o. b.i.d. for pain relief and presents for a total knee repair . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY : Medical : Significant for hypertension times 30 years , status post MI times two in 1983 and 1985 , TIA 's which led to an endarterectomy . Surgical history : Right carotid endarterectomy , status post CABG times six , status post TURP , status post ORIF of left arm . Medications : Labetalol 100 mg p.o. b.i.d. ; Enalapril 5 mg q.d. ; Naprosyn 500 mg b.i.d. ; Ranitidine 150 mg p.o.q. day ; Quinamm 1 p.o. q.h.s. p.r.n. ; KCl 20 mEq p.o. p.r.n. ; Ecotrin aspirin one p.o.q. day ; Ferrous Gluconate 325 mg p.o.q. day . Allergies : No known drug allergies . LABORATORY DATA : On admission the patient had a hematocrit of 32.3 , white blood cell count of 3.52 , glucose 94 , PT 12.2 , PTT 33.9 . Electrolytes : Sodium 136 , potassium 4.3 , chloride 102 , C02 31 , BUN 26 and creatinine 1.6 . Lab data on discharge : The patient had a white blood cell count of 7.1 and a hematocrit of 23.4 , PT 13.8 . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : GENERAL : Thin , well developed , well nourished white male in no acute distress . NECK : Without bruits . HEAD : NC / AT , PERRLA , EOMI , oropharynx clear . LUNGS : Clear . CHEST : Regular rate and rhythm , II / VI systolic ejection murmur , midline scar present . Abdomen : Benign . Rectal : Guaiac negative . EXTREMITIES : Mild bilateral knee effusion , bilateral varus deformity , right significantly greater than left . In terms of range of motion right head flexion to 120 degrees , extension 0 , left head flexion to 115 degrees , extension to 0 with positive crepitus bilaterally . HOSPITAL COURSE : The patient was taken to the operating room on 8-20-91 at which time a total knee repair was done to both the right and left knees . The patient tolerated the procedure well and returned to his room on postoperative day one . The patient did , on , postoperative day one have a bout of grossly heme positive emesis . He stated at this point that he did have a history of peptic ulcer disease and he did have a slow and continuous drop in his hematocrit until approximately postoperative day three . The patient also had episodes of significant temperature spikes sometimes to 102.6 . The patient was cultured multiple times , blood cultures , urine cultures and sputum cultures , all which were negative ( as well as chest x-ray ) . The temperature spikes did continue but have reached to a degree no higher than 100 degrees Farenheit and occurred a significantly decreased number of times . In terms of knee function , the patient has progressed very well and is ambulating approximately 12 feet on his own at this point . In terms of followup care , I would suggest that the patient have a gastroenterologist consult upon completion of Rehab and for further workup of his grossly heme positive emesis , with possible guaiac positive stool searching for a source of a bleed . The patient will be discharged on the following medications : Labetalol 100 mg p.o. b.i.d. ; Enalapril 5 mg p.o. q.d. ; Ranitidine 150 mg p.o. q.d. ; Ferrous Gluconate 325 mg p.o. b.i.d. ; Carafate one gram p.o. q.i.d. ; Quinamm one p.o. q.h.s. p.r.n. ; Percocet one to two p.o. q. 4 hours p.r.n. The patient 's condition on discharge is good . The patient will be discharged to a rehabilitation center and will be followed up by Dr. Nu Jescraln in six weeks from discharge . As stated above , it is suggested that the patient see his internist and possibly see a gastroenterologist for further workup in his grossly heme positive emesis as well as continued drop in hematocrit .
